The electrolyte label is attributed to dissolved salts because they dissociate into positively charged cations (ions) and negatively charged anions, which are free to move in a solvent like water. These charged particles can conduct electricity when placed in an electric field or when they come into contact with electrodes. The speaker emphasizes that it's the ions themselves that conduct electricity, not the water molecules. This concept is fundamental to understanding electrochemistry and the behavior of electrolytes in solutions.
